dc:description:
The DNAI2 gene was initially reported as a candidate gene linked to primary ciliary dyskinesia 9 (PCD 9) in 1999 and 2000 (Pennarun et al., PMID: 10577904, PMID:11153919). The specific disease entity, primary ciliary dyskinesia 9 (PCD 9) (MONDO: 0012906, OMIM # 612444), is part of a larger group of primary ciliary dyskinesias (PCD) and one of at least 50 monogenic causes of PCD. 

The onset of the symptoms and signs of the disease can occur at birth (Rocca MS et al., PMID:33167880), and the median age of diagnosis is 15 years old (Loges et al., PMID:18950741). The clinical features among well-characterized newborn patients with DNAI2 pathogenic mutations include neonatal respiratory distress, such as tachypnea or mild hypoxemia, requiring supplemental oxygen for a few hours to days after birth. In early childhood and later life, recurrent pneumonia is common. Otitis and rhinosinusitis are also reported. Approximately 50% of patients exhibit situs inversus or another form of reversed organ laterality and heterotaxy, in some cases including congenital transposition of the great vessels, pyloric stenosis, and other cardiac abnormalities. Patients can also be characterized by chronic sinusitis, as well as bronchiectasis in older individuals. Normal pressure hydrocephalus has been described in PCD (PMID: 31004071, PMID: 11912187, PMID: 31383820). Most men and women with PCD 9 have impaired and/or decreased fertility.
 
Additional diagnostic features include impaired or absent ciliary movement and radiological findings of bronchiectasis, mucous plugging, atelectasis, and lobar collapse. Nasal nitric oxide levels are very low or absent in these patients. However, among diagnostic features of PCD associated with pathogenic DNAI2 variants is exhibiting ciliary ultrastructure with an absence or shortening of outer dynein arms. 

This curation has scored five different suspected deleterious DNAI2 variants (one deleting exons 7-9, one nonsense variant in exon 7, one nonsense variant in exon 10, one splicing variant causing skipping of exon 11, and one splicing variant disrupting exon 4), which were collectively reported in 3 publications (PMID:18950741, PMID:23261302, PMID:33167880). All probands harbored biallelic homozygous variants that were confirmed to be trans. The molecular mechanism appears to be biallelic loss-of-function with an autosomal recessive mode of inheritance, characterized in at least some cases by variants predicted to trigger the absence of a gene product. 

This gene-disease relationship is also supported by experimental evidence. High levels of DNAI2 expression in humans are specific to tissues that harbor multi-ciliated cells, particularly the testis and trachea (PMID: 11153919 and PMID: 18950741). Loss of DNAI2 from the cilia of patients harboring other forms of PCD has been described and supports the functional role of DNAI2 in outer dynein arm assembly complexes throughout all respiratory ciliary axonemes and sperm (PMID: 18950741). Biochemical studies of the Chlamydomonas ortholog of DNAI2 indicate that the protein product is an intermediate dynein chain positioned at the base of the alpha-beta dimer of the outer dynein arms (PMID: 2147183). This is consistent with the ultrastructural defect characteristic of human patients. The protein also interacts with the Chlamydomonas ortholog of DNAI1 (2147183), a related intermediate dynein chain associated in humans with variants that cause PCD 1. Human patient phenotypes such as ciliary immotility and the absence of outer dynein arms are recapitulated by the Chlamydomonas model of DNAI2 loss of function (PMID:7698982) . Histopathology, infertility and lung damage phenotypes are recapitulated by mouse models of DNAI2 loss of function (PMID: 30387321). In addition, fish mutants with dnai2 loss-of-function exhibit a defect in outer dynein arms in the cilia axoneme, resulting in aberrant ciliary motility along with reversed organ laterality and situs inversus (PMID: 20709053). These phenotypic features are consistent with the pathogenicity of DNAI2 loss of function variants in PCD 9 patients.

In summary, DNAI2 is definitively associated with primary ciliary dyskinesia 9. This has been repeatedly demonstrated in both clinical diagnostic and research settings and has been upheld over time without the emergence of contradictory evidence, leading to a Definitive classification. This classification was approved by the ClinGen Motile Ciliopathy GCEP on August 11, 2022 (SOP Version 9).
curationReasonDescription: Adjust the scoring to account for the homozygous status of the variants in the patients.

evidence.dc:description: A good model for particular phenotypes of patients, however It gives lower score because this evidence has scored before from pervious publications regrading ODA defects.
Absent of ODA, cilia motility
evidence.rdfs:label: Chlamydomonas model of DNAI2 loss-of-function

evidence.dc:description: at the cilia and organs Transpositions
Immotile cillia, ODA defect situo inversus
evidence.rdfs:label: Fish with dnai2 loss-of-function

evidence.dc:description: The phenotypes are consistent with PCD but not highly specific for PCD (could be from acute or chronic respiratory disease). Thus, down-scoring of the model was performed.
infertility, pathology of the lung both are consistent with the human PCD patient
evidence.rdfs:label: Mouse model with DNAI2 Knockdown

evidence.dc:description: This evidence helps indicate that these patients have PCD, but does not specifically identify DNAI2 variants as the cause.
Similar ultrastructural ODA defects were observed in transmission electron microscopy of respiratory cilia from patient
evidence.rdfs:label: absent ODA

evidence.dc:description: This evidence is supporting the association of the gene with the ODA defect of the patients, but is not so specific to receive extra points as a phenotype.
the function of the protein is consistent with ODA effect from the patient
evidence.rdfs:label: DNAI2 ortholog localizes to the outer dynein arm

evidence.dc:description: This evidence from patient cilia is indicative that the patient has PCD but has been used to support the scoring of the variants rather than as experimental evidence.
This evidence shows that DNAI2 is part of the ciliary assembly, which is supporting the structural defect in the ciliary system of the human patients and is consistent with their phenotypes.
evidence.rdfs:label: Experimental data on Chlamydomonas model of DNAI2 loss-of-fu

evidence.dc:description: This experiment is consistent with the disease and the tissues in the body affected in the patients.

*DNAI2* mRNA was detected by northern blotting with DNAI2 cDNA across 15 different human tissues. Only trachea and testis showed high DNAI2 expression, while other tissues that lack multiciliated cells did not have detectable DNAI2 (Figure 4D). This data is highly compatible with the findings of a separate mouse experiment showing that knockdown of Dnaic2 expression triggers pulmonary alveolar damage, infertility, and morphological abnormalities of the sperm, ovaries, and fallopian tubes (PMID: 30387321).
evidence.rdfs:label: DNAI2 shows high levels of expression in trachea and testis

evidence.dc:description: This evidence shows that DNAI2 is part of the ciliary assembly, which is supporting the structural defect in the ciliary system of the human patients, and is consistent with their phenotypes. Up-scoring was performed because the phenomenon was seen in multiple different kinds of PCD patients.
In patients with *DNAH5* or *DNAI1* variants, DNAI2 protein is mislocalized (Figure 7). It is totally absent in the DNAH5 mutant (Figure 7B) and mostly absent from the DNAI1 mutant (Figure 7C).
evidence.rdfs:label: DNAI2 is absent from the cilia of patients with PCD.

evidence.dc:description: This data from the patient cells indicates that they have PCD, but does not specifically identify DNAI2 variants as the cause.

Mislocalization of the Outer Dynein Arm Heavy-Chain Protein DNAH5 in Respiratory Epithelial Cells from Patients with DNAI2 Mutations. Indicate that DNAH5 is essential for correct assembly of DNAI2 in both types of ODA complexes. and mutant DNAI1 inhibits assembly of DNAI2 predominantly in the distal ciliary axonemes
evidence.rdfs:label: Mislocalization of the Outer Dynein Arm Heavy-Chain DNAH5

evidence.dc:description: Cousins related
evidence.rdfs:label: UCL149 and UCL 150 Families

evidence.dc:description: The patient was scored at a high level initially because of the functional data. However, down-scoring was performed due to consanguinity.
The variant protein is missing from the respiratory cilia cells from the patient.

evidence.rdfs:label: UCL149Pa_Proband
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Fulfilled diagnostic criteria of primary ciliary dyskinesia

evidence.dc:description: While the paper reports the coordinates of the deletion as chr 17: 72295857-72301581, ClinVar reports them as chr 17: 72295847-72301591. This variant is a deletion of exons 7-9 of DNAI2, which has 14 total exons. Complete deletion of these three exons would cause a frameshift disrupting the protein product of all later exons. As a result, this deletion is predicted to trigger nonsense-mediated decay, or to at least disrupt the C-terminal 60% of the protein product
no functional data was found

evidence.rdfs:label: Case report, 2022
evidence.detectionMethod: The patient was initially genotyped using a next-generation sequencing panel focused on 36 genes known to harbor causal variants in PCD, revealing a homozygous deletion in the DNAI2 locus. Custom microarray-based CGH was used to confirm the presence of the 6.9 kb deletion.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText:
Diagnosed with primary ciliary dyskinesia with absence /shortened of outer dynein arms 
No family history of PCD. Nasal brushing showed a high number of inflammatory cells and bacteria. TEM showed absence or shortening of outer dynein arms in 100% of cells
Normal pressure hydrocephalus

evidence.dc:description:
Pedigree analysis is consistent with autosomal recessive mode of inheritance individuals had ciliary
outer dynein arm defects, homozygous c.1304G>A (p.W453*) mutation in exon 10
Only maternity variant was confirmed lowed the score

evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Fully diagnosed with primary ciliary dyskinesia

evidence.rdfs:label: UNC 80-IV-2 # 453
evidence.detectionMethod: Whole-exome resequencing was used to genotype the patient, while homozygosity mapping was also performed as part of a larger effort to identify homozygous variants in the cohort (not applicable to this patient). Sanger sequencing is likely to have been performed for confirmation, although it is not described for this specific patient.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Fully diagnosed with primary ciliary dyskinesia with ODA defects
evidence.previousTestingDescription: Whole-exome resequencing (WER) was performed, in combination with homozygosity mapping. The patient was part of a larger cohort of 31 probands and family members.

evidence.dc:description: Even though the patient harbor DNAI2 mutations consistent with loss-of-function mutations. lowed the score because of function assay of the High-resolution immunofluorescence imaging to detect the ODA heavy dynein chains DNAH5 and DNAH9 in respiratory cells from patient showed an aberrant expression pattern for DNAH5 and DNAH9.

Absence of DNAI2 in Respiratory Epithelial Cells from Patients with Primary Ciliary Dyskinesia.
DNAI2 is not detectable, consistent with recessive loss-of-function mutations that result in the failure to produce a functional DNAI2 protein.

The variant is a splicing acceptor site disruption and is proven to have an effect on protein expression in patient cells. The variant was low-scored more because the patient is homozygous, yet the genotyping method did not identify other suspicious PCD variants.
The variant protein is absent from respiratory epithelial cells from patients with PCD.

evidence.rdfs:label: OP42-II2
evidence.detectionMethod: Whole exome confirmed by genotyping of family members.
evidence.previousTestingDescription: Patient was previously tested for DNAH5 exons (normal). Also, whole exome was used for genotyping
